title: I cannot afford to pay back an online installment loan. What are the chances of the case being dismissed in Small Claims Court ?
question: I tried to arrange a re-payment agreement with the company but they will not stop charging me fees. I will not ever be able to repay them. I am sure they will sue me in court eventually, what chances do I have of winning and not having to repay them? I heard that some installment loan companies operate illegally in California, would you know if Cash Call and Advance America are some of them?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Fees,Small claims court
answers: Filing a lawsuit, small claims or otherwise, requires the plaintiff to voluntarily subject itself to the jurisdiction of your local court. Most on line lenders are not interested in filing lawsuits, because they are then subject to any counterclaims you might bring. Many of them are based on Indian reservations, where they can claim immunity in lawsuits against them, but that is not available if they start a lawsuit against you in your local court. They feel they can break local and state laws in their debt collection efforts, as long as they never have to deal with the state and local courts. If an action is actually brought (unlikely), you need an attorney well versed in the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. Since the Act allows for the recovery of attorney fees, you can likely consult with one free to review you situation.

What makes you so sure this creditor will sue you? Because they threaten to do so by phone? Because you haven't paid them?
Rather than worrying about what will happen if you are sued and whether your case can be dismissed due to some far-fetched legal theory, focus on what is in your control and what is actually happening. Chances are in your favor that you will not be sued. Do you have other debts besides this one? You should schedule a consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your community to discuss all of your bankruptcy and non-bankruptcy options for dealing with this debt and others, if applicable. Stop worrying about things that may never happen and take control of the situation by arming yourself with all of your legal options so that you can make the best decision and move forward with your life.
Best of luck.

You need to send them a letter requesting that they verify the debt, and do not contact you by phone. If they do sue you, you can possibly counter sue for violations of the FDCPA, breach of the agreement, and this might actually end up making you money. So the short answer is to not sweat it after you take some preliminary steps.

Do not believe anything that a debt collector tells you. Payday lenders and other high interest lenders rarely file lawsuit. Instead they just threaten and annoy people. If they do sue, they must present evidence that is admissible in court. If they file a civil action, it will be a year before the case goes to trial. If I were you, I would get complete contact (physical address not just a PO Box, legal corporate name, full name of the persons, telephone and fax numbers, information about the debt collector and then send a "Do Not Call" letter.
